title: 105_hr3157
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teachers in the Classroom Act". It includes findings related to teachers. Congress finds that enrollment in elementary and secondary schools is at record levels, with an expected increase of over a million students in 1998. The increase in student enrollment will continue for the next decade, particularly affecting high poverty urban and rural areas and states with rapid population growth. Schools will need to expand to accommodate the growing number of students. To keep up with the growing student population, schools will need to hire 150,000 additional teachers in the next decade. Research shows that students in smaller classes learn more in the early grades and maintain an academic edge even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. Adequate education and preparation are crucial. It is important to adequately educate and prepare America's children for the competitive global economy by improving the learning environment for each student. Congress should fund positions for teachers without increasing the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt, and provide resources to keep pace with growing enrollment and reduce classroom sizes if possible. The grant program is established to improve the learning environment for students without increasing bureaucracy or debt. The Secretary of Education can award grants to Governors for hiring teachers to reduce overcrowded classes. Governors must apply to receive the grant, and local educational agencies must establish a trust fund for the funds received. The agency must establish a trust fund for payments received under the Act and ensure funds are used to hire new teachers within 2 years. They must follow accounting practices set by the Governor, allow state access to records, and increase the number of teachers in classrooms. Personnel hired under the Act must be reviewed annually for performance. The agency must review annually the performance of personnel hired under the Act, obligate them for a one-year period, repay any unspent funds to the State within 27 months, use funds to supplement non-Federal sources for student education, and apply for funding annually from the Governor. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State receives funds based on the number of children aged 5-17. Unused funds are reallocated to other States. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. Annual review of personnel performance, fund repayment, supplementing non-Federal sources for education, and annual funding application from the Governor. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. A Governor can withhold payments to a local educational agency for noncompliance with section 3(c) after 60 days notice. The agency must increase teachers or qualified personnel to continue receiving funds. SEC. 6. PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies based on the need to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must evaluate and report on the funds used by the agencies annually and can use up to 2 percent of the funds for administrative costs. Additionally, Governors can use funds for innovative teaching programs. Governors receiving grants under this Act can allocate up to 2 percent for administrative costs and up to 10 percent for innovative teaching programs. The Secretary of Education must report annually on program effectiveness and make recommendations for program continuity. SEC. 7. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not provide tenure to personnel hired under it. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. Defines "local educational agency," "State," and "Secretary" for the purposes of this Act. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $500 million for 1999, $1 billion for 2000, $1.5 billion for 2001, $2 billion for 2002, and $2.5 billion for 2003.
